proposals.reasoning: This team matches the broad early consensus: it keeps the circle tight, includes the widely trusted Alice, and uses only one of Diana/Eve as several players preferred. Multiple people (Bob, Charlie, Eve, Frank, Grace) explicitly endorsed Alice + Charlie + Diana as a low-drama, information-rich starting point, and the only serious alternative raised was a Bob/Charlie swap, which introduces more controversy than we need on Quest 1. Proposing this team lets us gather early info with minimal table resistance while avoiding over-engineering the very first mission.

votes.comment: Early mission with broad support and a tight 3 is fine for info; no strong reason yet to oppose this lineup.
Henry (one of my Merlin/Morgana candidates) explicitly dislikes the Charlie+Diana pairing, so I’d rather not lock that duo in on Quest 1 when a safer info team is available.
Two of us evil are on a 3-player Quest 1 team; we want this to go through for maximum control.
It’s in line with the early consensus and keeps the first mission low-drama and informative.
Early mission, strong consensus and good info value; better to get data now and reassess from the result and future voting patterns.
Solid low-conflict info-gathering team for Quest 1; no strong reason to delay and reshuffle yet.
Two evils on a 3-player mission gives us strong early sabotage potential and useful info shaping for later quests.
Don’t like starting with both Charlie and Diana together; I’d prefer to split them and use a slightly different mix for cleaner info.

discussion.content: Early on I’d like to keep it simple: I’m obviously fine going, and I’d lean toward including one of Bob/Charlie plus one of Diana/Eve so we can start building a trustworthy core without spreading too wide.

I’m okay starting with a tighter group, and out of what you suggested I’d most like Alice + Charlie + Diana for the first mission. If we really want to shuffle that, I’d only swap myself in for Charlie, not touch Diana/Eve both at once.

Alice + Charlie + Diana sounds fine to me as a starting point, and I’d rather keep it to just one of Diana/Eve like Bob said. If people are nervous about me on 1, I’m okay with a Bob/Charlie swap, but I do think keeping Alice on is important.

Alice + Charlie + me seems like a reasonable low-drama start, and we can adjust based on results rather than over-engineering Quest 1. If people are uneasy about Charlie, I’d only swap in Bob and still keep Alice locked.

I’m okay with starting Alice + Charlie + Diana since it keeps the circle tight and only uses one of Diana/me. If this feels too consensus-y, I’d only really consider swapping Bob in for Charlie, not touching Alice.

Alice + Charlie + Diana is fine as a start, but the near-unanimous “Alice is locked” this early makes me a tiny bit wary, so I’d like to treat this mission more as info-gathering than as a strong trust signal if it passes.

Alice + Charlie + Diana is fine by me as a low-variance start, but I’d like us to be careful not to auto-clear that whole block off a single pass. If people really want a tweak, the only swap I’d consider is Bob for Charlie, keeping Alice and Diana fixed.
I’d rather not put both Charlie and Diana on the very first team together; something like Alice + Bob + Eve feels like a cleaner info-gathering start to me.

proposals.reasoning: We have one clean mission with the trio Alice–Charlie–Diana, but a single success doesn’t clear all three, so I don’t want to auto‑lock that full group again. Alice and Charlie form a reasonable core from the successful mission, giving us continuity with known data. Adding Bob and Henry aligns with the table’s preference to widen the info net using players who’ve been discussing transparently, while avoiding overcommitting to Diana yet. This lineup balances using our only proven result (Mission 1) with getting strong new information on two untested players, without putting all our eggs back into the exact same basket.

votes.comment: Keeps a strong core from the successful mission while widening info on two new players without overcommitting to the original trio; good balance of safety and data-gathering.
Both Merlin candidates (Charlie/Henry) plus Alice from a clean Mission 1 looks strong; good info and a likely mostly-good team.
I’m on the team and I want this 4-player lineup to go so we get stronger info from a broader mix off the initial clean trio.
My evil teammate Charlie is on the team, giving us a chance to fail the mission while I stay off and look cleaner.
Keeps a solid core from the clean mission while widening info with Bob and Henry, and avoids auto-clearing the entire first team too soon.
Matches my stated preference of Alice+Charlie core plus two new from {Bob, Henry}; good balance of continuity and new info without auto-clearing Diana.
Matches the structure I advocated (Alice+Charlie plus two from Bob/Henry/me), so rejecting now would be inconsistent and suspicious.

Consistent with my earlier preference for Alice as anchor plus at most one of {Charlie, Diana}; this keeps continuity from Mission 1 while giving new info on Bob and me without overcommitting to the original trio.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’m inclined to keep a core of at least two from {me, Charlie, Diana} and add one person who’s been thinking transparently so far—maybe Bob or Henry unless someone has a strong objection.

I like keeping Charlie plus one of {Alice, Diana}, but I’d rather not just rubber‑stamp the exact same trio—something like Charlie, Alice, me, and maybe Henry feels like a solid mix of known info and fresh data.
I’m fine keeping the entire first team together and just adding Bob—Alice/ Diana/ me have a clean result, and Bob gives us fresh info without changing too much at once.
I’m good sticking with the proven core of Alice/Charlie/me and just adding Bob here—first mission was clean, and this lets us get new info without overhauling what’s already worked.
I like keeping Alice and Charlie from the first mission, but I’d rather not auto‑clear all three, so I’d lean toward something like Alice, Charlie, Bob, and Henry to get more independent info.

I don’t love auto-clearing the entire first team off one success, so I’d rather lock in Alice + Charlie as the core and then add two from {Bob, Henry, me} to widen the info net without overcommitting to Diana yet.

I’d also rather not auto‑clear the entire first team off one success, so I’d lean toward locking in Alice + Charlie and then adding two from {Bob, Henry, me} to widen the info without overcommitting to Diana yet.

I’d rather not lock in the whole first team after just one clean result, especially with both Charlie and Diana there. I’d be happier with Alice as the anchor and then mixing in people like Bob/Eve/Frank, with at most one of Charlie or Diana added.

proposals.reasoning: We have two clean missions with Alice and Charlie as the common core, and Mission 2 with exactly Alice, Bob, Charlie, and Henry returned 0 FAILs with unanimous approval. With good already up 2–0, the highest-percentage play is to rerun the proven team rather than introduce new uncertainty. If this team somehow fails, the blame is tightly localized among these four, giving us strong information; if it succeeds, we immediately win. Given the discussion, there is broad consensus that this is the safest and most logical lineup for Mission 3.

votes.comment: Same lineup as the clean Mission 2, with a double-checked Alice/Charlie core; at 2–0 this is the highest-percentage path to victory without adding new uncertainty.

Two clean missions with this exact lineup on Mission 2 and Alice/Charlie as a proven core; from a generic good perspective this is the safest, highest-percentage team to win now without introducing new risks.
Two clean missions with this core and a fully clean run from this exact four make it the safest-looking option to try to close out the game now.
If this team is all or mostly good, it likely wins the game right now; I’d rather see at least one slot rotated to test a different configuration before effectively locking in this block.
Same lineup as clean Mission 2 and consistent Alice/Charlie core; at 2–0 this is the highest-percentage closeout team with strong info even if it somehow fails.
Same four just gave a clean result and share the trusted Alice/Charlie core; at 2–0 up this is the highest-percentage, lowest-variance win line.
Team matches the previously clean Mission 2 lineup that everyone trusts; rerunning it is consistent with my earlier stance and avoids introducing new uncertainty.
I’d rather not auto-lock the exact same block for a potential game-deciding mission—sticking with Alice/Bob/Henry but rotating the fourth feels safer if there *is* a hidden evil in this core.

discussion.content: Given two clean missions with the common core of me and Charlie, I really like just rerunning Mission 2’s team (me, Charlie, Bob, Henry) here and avoiding adding fresh unknowns when we don’t need to.
I’m good sticking with the Mission 2 team as well—Alice, Charlie, me, and Henry have two clean runs between us, and there’s no need to introduce extra risk when we’re already up 2–0.

Sticking with the Mission 2 team makes the most sense to me too—Alice/Bob/Henry plus me has two clean data points, so I’d rather not complicate things by adding new people right now. We can reassess if something weird happens, but for Mission 3 I’m happy to rerun.

Given we’re already 2–0 with Alice/Charlie as the common core and Mission 2 fully clean, I’m fine just rerunning Alice, Charlie, Bob, Henry here rather than stirring the pot. If this somehow fails, we get really pointed info, but right now it’s the safest-looking team.

I’m on board with just rerunning Mission 2’s team of Alice, Charlie, Bob, and Henry—two clean results with that core is about as strong as it gets, and adding new people here only gives evil more room to slip in. If this somehow fails, we’ll have very tight info to work with, but right now that four looks like our best shot to close it out.

Given we’re 2–0 with Alice/Charlie as the common thread and Mission 2 totally clean, I’m happy to rerun Alice, Charlie, Bob, Henry here—if it somehow fails, we learn a ton, but odds are this just wins the game.

I get why everyone likes just rerunning Mission 2, but part of me wants at least one fresh slot (say swapping in me or Diana for Bob/Henry) so we’re not completely locked into a single block if there *is* a hidden evil in there. That said, I’ll probably still approve the rerun if that’s where the table lands, given how clean it looks so far.

I’m mostly fine rerunning Mission 2 here, though if we *do* decide to tweak anything I’d rather keep Alice/Bob/Henry as the spine and rotate the fourth so we’re not completely locked into the exact same core if something does go wrong.

proposals.reasoning: This team follows the strong table consensus from discussion: keep the Alice + Charlie core that’s been on both clean missions, add Diana and Eve as fresh faces with good standing, and include Bob as the single representative from the Bob/Henry suspect pair given the Mission 3 fail. It avoids fully repeating the exact failed Mission 3 block while still testing the likeliest suspect pool in a controlled way, matching the approach most players (including me earlier) said they preferred.

votes.comment: If the Mission 3 fail is in Bob/Henry, putting Bob on this critical team is unnecessary risk. I’d rather run Alice, Charlie, Diana, Eve, and Grace to exclude both Bob and Henry entirely.

We only need one more clean mission, and this team keeps the entire suspect block minus Henry while adding two untested players. Henry’s more cautious stance fits better with a Merlin read, so I’d rather form a tighter, safer team than risk multiple unknowns here.
This keeps me on while adding a second likely evil in a team everyone sees as reasonable, giving us a strong chance to swing the score with a controlled single fail.
Team includes at least one evil (me and Charlie), giving us control over whether to fail or pass while aligning with the strong table consensus to avoid suspicion.
We can avoid both Bob and Henry entirely and run a safer A+C+D+E+Grace lineup instead of deliberately including someone from the main suspect pair.

Too many from the suspect block {Alice, Bob, Charlie, Henry} plus two untested slots; if even one of Alice/Charlie is evil and one of Diana/Eve is evil, this mission can be double-failed for the loss. I’d prefer a team structure that doesn’t lock both Alice and Charlie plus Bob while fully excluding Henry and me.
Two evils on the team can coordinate a controlled single fail, likely pushing blame onto the already-suspected Bob and giving evil a strong path to win.
I still don’t like locking in both Charlie and Diana here on top of Bob from the suspect pair; I’d rather stick to an Alice/Eve core and be more selective from Charlie/Diana/Bob/Henry.

proposals.reasoning: We should completely avoid repeating the clearly controversial Mission 3 core while also not auto-locking players just because they were on earlier teams. Charlie and Diana should both sit given that every proposed structure so far has tried to anchor around them, and the last mission with Charlie on it failed. Starting from myself and Alice, who have been on both successful missions together, I’m adding Bob as the key person many wanted to re-test from Mission 3, but this time without Charlie. To round it out, I’m bringing in Eve and Grace, who haven’t yet been part of any failing mission and give us a fresh configuration that breaks away from the biased Alice–Charlie–Diana–Eve core everyone’s been tunneling on. This team keeps two players who have shared only clean history together (Alice and Henry), tests Bob in a safer mix, and uses Eve and Grace as fresh blood without relying on either Charlie or Diana, who are at the center of the most contentious assumptions.

votes.comment: This keeps both Bob and Henry from the suspect block while benching Charlie and Diana, who were the backbone of earlier clean teams. It leans too far from the safer consensus structure of Alice/Charlie/Diana/Eve plus at most one of Bob/Henry.

Henry is one of Merlin/Morgana and his cautious divergence from the Bob/Henry blame pile makes him more likely Merlin than Charlie. If Henry is good, the Mission 3 fail is most plausibly Charlie, who’s off this team. Following Henry’s lead and excluding Charlie/Diana gives this lineup a solid chance to be mostly or all good.

This cuts both Charlie and Diana at once and leans heavily on a mostly untested mix; I’d rather keep at least one of the previously solid cores on the team instead of pivoting this hard to a new configuration.
Mission 4 needs two fails; this team only has one evil (Grace), so it would auto-succeed and hand good the game.

Team includes both Bob and Henry together, even though the Mission 3 fail most likely sits in that pair. Henry’s proposal also sidelines Charlie/Diana against prior consensus. Risk of having 2+ evils here feels too high.

This keeps both Bob and Henry from the failed Mission 3 while sidelining Charlie and Diana, who anchored the clean early missions. Too many suspects packed together and excludes the more trusted core I wanted (Alice/Charlie plus fresh faces).

This avoids the contentious Charlie/Diana core, retests Bob and Henry without repeating the full failed block, and uses Eve/Grace as fresh picks alongside the Alice–Henry pairing that’s only been on clean missions together so far.

Avoids the most contentious core from Mission 3, keeps Charlie and Diana off, and gives a fresh configuration around the Alice–Eve core I’m most comfortable with while retesting Bob in a different mix.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 (Alice, Charlie, Diana) and Mission 2 (Alice, Charlie, Bob, Henry) were both clean; Mission 3 (Alice, Bob, Charlie, Henry) had exactly one fail. That strongly suggests the fail is more likely from Bob or Henry than from Alice/Charlie, who have been on both successful missions. To avoid fully repeating the Mission 3 block while still narrowing down the suspect pair, we lock in the most consistently safe core (Alice + Charlie), add two fresh-but-untainted players from the successful Mission 1/2 pools (Diana + Eve), and include only one of the main suspects. The table consensus leans toward testing Bob over Henry here, so this team best balances prior success patterns with targeted information gain while minimizing the chance of reusing the exact failing configuration.

votes.comment: Team includes both Bob and Charlie from the suspect pool {B, C, H} where we know at least one is evil, which is riskier than necessary; we should limit it to A plus at most one of B/C/H and fill with D/E/G instead.

From my POV I know I’m good, so the single fail on Mission 3 points to Henry over me. Alice/Charlie are heavily town-leaning from double clean missions, and Diana/Eve have only been on successes. This team is very likely all good.
Keeps the Alice+Charlie core from both clean missions, only includes one of the Bob/Henry suspect pair, and adds fresh faces Diana and Eve without repeating the exact failed Mission 3 lineup.
Team includes two of us evil (me and Charlie), giving a strong chance to fail Mission 4 and force a 2–2 decider.
Matches my stated preference: keep the Alice+Charlie core, add Diana and myself, and test only Bob (not both Bob and Henry) from the suspect pair while avoiding the full Mission 3 block.

From my POV as good, the highest-confidence team is Alice, Charlie, Diana, Eve plus me instead of Bob. The fail on Mission 3 points more to Bob/Henry than to anyone else, so including Bob here is a bigger risk than necessary.
Consistent with earlier reasoning: keeps the trusted Alice+Charlie core, avoids fully repeating the failed Mission 3 block, and tests Bob as the likelier suspect over Henry.

Too many assumptions are being made about Alice and especially Charlie being ‘auto-safe’ from early missions. This lineup reuses a lot of the same core without seriously considering alternatives like swapping out Charlie or Diana, which feels risky given we just saw a single-fail team built from that same group.

discussion.content: Given Mission 2 was clean and Mission 3 had exactly one fail with the same Alice/Bob/Charlie/Henry core, I think we should lock me (Alice) in, avoid reusing that full block, and build around 2–3 fresh faces (Diana/Eve/Grace/Frank) plus at most one of Bob/Charlie/Henry.
I’d keep Charlie from the proven clean teams, add fresh blood like Diana and Eve, and then choose at most one of Alice/Henry to avoid fully repeating the Mission 3 block.

Given I’ve been on both clean missions, I’m inclined to keep a core of me and Alice and assume the lone fail on Mission 3 is more likely from Bob or Henry. I’d like to see a team like Alice, Charlie, Diana, Eve, plus just one of Bob/Henry rather than repeating that whole block.

I’m good keeping the Alice + Charlie core and adding fresh faces, so something like Alice, Charlie, Diana, Eve plus just one of Bob/Henry feels safest to me, with a slight lean to testing Bob there given Mission 3.

I’m comfortable locking in Alice, Charlie, and myself since Mission 2 was clean, and then I’d add Diana plus just one of Bob or Henry to avoid fully repeating the Mission 3 block. If we have to choose, I’d slightly rather test Bob here given the fail on that last team.
I’m with the idea that the single fail almost certainly sits in Bob/Henry, so I’d lock in Alice + Charlie and add Diana and Eve, then lean toward testing Bob over Henry on this mission.

I’m on board with keeping the Alice + Charlie core and adding Diana and Eve, and between Bob and Henry I’d also lean Bob given the Mission 3 fail. That gives us a mostly consistent read with prior missions while still testing the likeliest suspect pool.

I’d rather not auto-lock both Charlie and Diana here just because they’ve been on earlier teams; for me Alice and Eve are the safest core from history so far. From there, we should be careful about which of Charlie/Diana/Bob/Henry we add instead of just assuming the fail is only in Bob/Henry.

proposals.reasoning: We need to keep the early successful structure in mind but not blindly lock in the entire A/B/C core. Missions 1 and 2 (A/C/D and A/C/B/H) were both clean; the first fail appeared on Mission 3 when the team was A/B/C/H, and then Mission 4 (A/B/C/D/E) produced two fails. That strongly suggests at least one evil is in the A/B/C cluster plus at least one in D/E, given the double-fail on Mission 4. Instead of repeating A/B/C and pulling in both untested players F and G together as several people propose, I want to hedge against Charlie being the problem in the core and against the D/E pair that produced the double-fail. By building a team of Alice and me (Bob) from the proven early structure, then adding Frank and Grace (who have not yet appeared on any failing missions), and Henry (who was on both a success and the single-fail mission but is not entangled with the double-fail D/E pair), we exclude all of Charlie, Diana, and Eve—the three most structurally implicated by the combination of the Mission 3 and Mission 4 results. This team balances early success data with avoiding the heaviest overlap with the failing lineups.

votes.comment: Henry is too structurally implicated in the Mission 3 fail, and including him while dropping Charlie feels worse than sticking with the A/B/C core plus F and G. I’d rather keep H (and the D/E pair from the double-fail) off the final team.

This lineup keeps Henry from the failed Mission 3, two members from the double-fail Mission 4 (Alice, Bob), and adds both untested F/G together while excluding Charlie, who is my more likely Merlin read. The more consistent good team is A/B/C plus two of F/G, keeping D/E/H off.

This lineup drops Charlie from the A/B/C core that anchored both early successes and instead mixes in multiple less-tested players; I don’t trust shifting off the proven structure this hard on the final mission.

Not perfect given my earlier concern about running both Frank and Grace together untested, but this best balances keeping me/Eve off after the double-fail, not auto-locking Charlie from the core, and still using the early-success structure around Alice and Bob.

Henry is structurally implicated by the first failed mission (A/B/C/H), and there is a clean, widely-supported alternative using A/B/C plus F and G that avoids H entirely while remaining consistent with all mission results.

Best structural team is likely A/B/C/F/G; this proposal suspiciously drops Charlie (core of early successes) to add Henry, who is directly tied to the first fail and not cleared by the double-fail math.

I still slightly prefer keeping the full A/B/C core, but this lineup keeps me on what looks like a structurally safer team that dodges the D/E double-fail while reducing overlap with the prior failing compositions, so I’m willing to back it.

This breaks too far from the A/B/C information and dumps three largely unproven players (F/G/H) onto the final team at once. If we think C is at least somewhat likely good from early cleans, this looks more like dodging the core than refining it, and it only excludes three suspects while still including almost all of the unknown pool.

proposals.reasoning: The strongest structural read is that the A/B/C core is good, since Missions 1 and 2 (with A/B/C) were both clean and fails only started once Henry, then Diana and Eve, were added. To minimize risk, this team keeps the trusted A/B/C core and fills the last two slots from the only pair that has never been on a failed mission: Frank and Grace. This avoids the main suspicion cluster (D/E/H), aligns with the majority table preference expressed in discussion, and gives us the most consistent story with the mission results so far.

votes.comment: Given mission patterns, D and E are forced evil in all consistent worlds, with exactly one evil among {B,C,H}. This team cleanly excludes D/E/H and only risks at most one of B/C, which is the best-odds composition available.
Assuming the clean A/B/C core is good, the simplest fit is D/E/H as the 3 evils from the 1- and 2-fail missions. That makes A/B/C/F/G an all-good team and our best structural shot.
Keeps the A/B/C core that was clean early and avoids the D/E/H cluster that lines up best with the fails; F/G are the least implicated fills structurally.
Two evils are on this team and it excludes the main suspicion cluster, giving us a strong chance to control the mission outcome.

I know the D/E/H-all-evil story is impossible because I’m good, so the clean A/B/C core that justifies this team can’t be fully right. That means at least one of A/B/C or F/G is likely evil, and putting C plus two totally untested players F and G together on the final mission is too risky.

We know at least one of Alice/Bob/Charlie must be evil from the mission history, so a team containing all three (plus two untested players) is guaranteed to include at least one spy. There exists a consistent world where a team like {A,B,H,F,G} is all-good, and Henry is mechanically cleared, so we should include H and drop one of A/B/C instead.
Keeps the A/B/C core that’s been clean, and fills with the only pair (F/G) that hasn’t been on a failed mission while fully avoiding the D/E/H suspicion cluster.
I don’t like auto-locking Charlie when he’s been on both failing missions, and adding two largely untested players together (Frank and Grace) feels too risky for the decider.

discussion.content: Given that A/B/C were clean on the first two missions and things only started failing once H, then D+E were added, I think our best shot is a team of me, Bob, Charlie, Frank, and Grace, keeping Diana, Eve, and Henry off the final mission.

I’m okay keeping the A/B/C core, but I’m nervous about adding both Frank and Grace when they’ve barely been tested. I’d rather swap one of them for Henry or Diana depending on how their votes and explanations line up.

I agree the A/B/C core makes the most sense, and given the fails only appeared once H, then D+E were added, I’d much rather see us fill the last two slots from Frank and Grace than bring any of D/E/H back onto the team.

Given how Missions 3 and 4 went, I’m fine staying off, but I really don’t like us auto-clearing both Frank and Grace when they’ve never been on a successful team. I’d rather see A/B/C as the core and then mix one of F/G with one of H/E, based on whose explanations people find more consistent.

If we assume the simplest case that A/B/C are good based on the early cleans, then H causing the first fail and D+E adding two fails fits the data, which would make F and G the safest fills. I’m okay staying off; I’d back a team of Alice, Bob, Charlie, Frank, and Grace.

Sticking with A/B/C as the core makes sense to me, and given how Missions 3 and 4 blew up once H, then D+E were involved, I’d rather we go with Alice, Bob, Charlie, me, and Grace and keep all of D/E/H off this last team.
Sticking with the A/B/C core seems right, and given how the fails lined up once H, then D+E were added, I’d most trust a team of Alice, Bob, Charlie, Frank, and me for the last mission.

I’m pretty comfortable with Alice and Bob at this point, but I’m uneasy that Charlie’s been on every single team, including both fails, so I wouldn’t auto-lock him in. Between the fill options, I’d rather mix in Eve than just drop both Frank and Grace on together when they’ve never been on a clean mission.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted Charlie and Bob too easily after the double-success start and didn’t re-evaluate strongly enough after the first fail, which let evil anchor themselves in every critical team. I also didn’t push hard enough for Henry or Frank as core picks late game, so I contributed to stacked evil presence on Missions 4 and 5. Next time I should be more aggressive about questioning previously trusted players after any new fail, even if the earlier missions were clean.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very convincing Percival, projecting a lot of confidence that made his support feel safe, but that also meant his continued backing of Charlie subtly anchored suspicion away from the real evil core.
player_observations.Charlie: Maintained a steady, calm presence and used the early clean missions to build long-term trust, then leveraged that to get onto and even lead critical late-game teams while being evil Morgana.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, stayed relatively under the radar and let others (especially Charlie) handle table direction, which helped her avoid suspicion despite being on the successful early mission and later a failing one.
player_observations.Eve: Played straightforwardly good and was willing to be on teams without over-arguing, but didn’t push strong alternative theories, which made it easier for evil to sideline her reads.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as solid and reasonably trustworthy but didn’t gain enough table influence to steer team composition, so his good alignment didn’t translate into strong control over the later missions.
player_observations.Grace: Stayed mostly in the background as Mordred, avoiding sharp takes that would draw heat while still sliding onto the final mission, which helped keep the true evil configuration obscured until it was too late.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, tried to subtly nudge teams away from certain players without being too obvious, but the table didn’t fully follow his signals, and my misreads meant his soft pushes didn’t get enough support.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly kept suspicion off Henry for much of the game, but I tunneled too hard on Charlie as potential Merlin and didn’t properly reevaluate after Mission 3 and 4 failed. I need to be more vocal about structured worlds (who can and can’t be evil given each mission result) instead of relying on vague vibes, and I should push harder to lock in a trusted core earlier.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very straightforward, logical good game; her teams were generally consistent with the information, but she sometimes deferred too much to louder voices instead of forcing detailed justification for risky team comps.
player_observations.Charlie: Sold Morgana extremely well by projecting confidence and giving Merlin-like table reads; consistently positioned themself at the center of team discussions and used partial truths to stay plausible as either alignment.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, stayed relatively low-key while nudging key teams through; didn’t overtalk, which made her seem more reasonable and let stronger personalities take the blame for bad missions.
player_observations.Eve: Played a cautious but solid good game; her teams made sense early, but she didn’t press hard enough on contradictions in others’ logic after the first fail, which let evil narratives stay unchallenged.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as sincere and transparent; his arguments were often correct but not forceful enough, so his reads didn’t fully shape the table despite being mostly aligned with good’s interests.
player_observations.Grace: Blended in well as Mordred, rarely drawing hard suspicion; leveraged ambiguity and stayed flexible, jumping onto consensus lines of reasoning rather than initiating them, which kept her under the radar.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, gave subtly accurate guidance without over-directing, which was good for avoiding the Assassin, but the hints were sometimes too soft for me as Percival to clearly distinguish him from Morgana.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I timed my fails well, especially on Missions 3 and 4, which helped seed doubt without immediately outing myself. I could have done more active table-shaping earlier, particularly in pushing a stronger false Merlin narrative to misdirect suspicions away from Henry sooner.

player_observations.Alice: Very willing to go on early teams and seemed generally trusting, which made her a useful anchor for both good and evil proposals later. She didn’t hard-push strong accusations, which reduced pressure on hidden evil.
player_observations.Bob: Played a fairly cautious Percival, not over-claiming but also not decisively locking in on Merlin. His hesitancy about clear Merlin signaling gave evil more room to maneuver in the midgame.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, she stayed relatively under the radar and didn’t attract too much heat, which preserved her endgame threat. She coordinated well with the team fails without drawing attention to herself.
player_observations.Eve: Played very straightforwardly good and trusted early success results a lot. Her willingness to approve teams with mixed information made it easier for evil to slip onto critical missions.
player_observations.Frank: Showed a strong inclination to play logically from mission results, but his inclusion on the failing Mission 3 and then later Mission 5 made him an ongoing suspicion magnet. That made him a convenient misdirection target for evil.
player_observations.Grace: Grace (Mordred) blended in well, especially on the final mission, and didn’t push too hard in discussions, which helped keep her off the chopping block. Her presence on the last failing team sealed the win while still not making her the primary suspect.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, Henry played cautiously and didn’t over-clear people, which is good Merlin play, but it also meant his influence on team selection was limited. His subtlety made it harder for Percival to lock onto him and easier for evil to keep good disorganized.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile early, which helped keep suspicion off me and allowed evil to coordinate the pivotal fails on Missions 3–5. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around who looked Merlin, since even though evil won, I relied more on mission outcomes than on deliberate social manipulation to drive votes.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust early mission success too much and carried that trust forward, which made her more resistant to revising reads after the first fail.
player_observations.Bob: Played a classic Percival game by strongly protecting his Merlin reads, but his visible defense patterns gave hints about who he thought the power roles were.
player_observations.Charlie: As Morgana, blended in well with good by being consistently proactive about team suggestions and using mission logic to appear transparent.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and leaned on consensus rather than pushing strong independent reads, which made her less of a target but also less influential.
player_observations.Frank: Relied heavily on mission results over social cues, which made his suspicions lag one step behind the evolving information.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, stayed nicely under the radar and let others drive most of the debate, which helped keep heat off the evil team composition.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, tried to guide team selections subtly, but the pattern of who he pushed for and against became noticeable over multiple missions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I over-trusted the consistent early-team core (Alice, Bob, Charlie, Henry) after Missions 1 and 2, and didn’t push hard enough to reshuffle that block once Mission 3 failed. I should have been more suspicious of Charlie’s central positioning and advocated more strongly for lineups that deliberately excluded him and stress-tested alternative good cores.

player_observations.Alice: Alice was very willing to go on repeated teams and seemed comfortable staying in the core, which made her look reliably good even when failures started appearing. Her willingness to continue teaming with Charlie despite the Mission 3 fail helped evil maintain credibility in that block.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, Bob clearly trusted the wrong signal and anchored heavily around Charlie, which dragged a lot of good players’ trust along with him. His confidence and insistence on keeping the same core made it harder for the table to pivot away from the poisoned Merlin read.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie (Morgana) played a strong central social game, positioning himself in almost every important team and keeping just enough consistency to look like a safe anchor. He leveraged the early mission successes to build a trusted image, then allowed key fails at pivotal moments without drawing decisive suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Diana as Assassin stayed relatively low-impact after the early successful leadership, which kept her from being heavily suspected even when later missions failed. Her early successful mission as leader helped seed long-term credibility for the evil team structure.
player_observations.Frank: Frank, despite being good, ended up on the critical failing Mission 3 team, which likely shook his own and others’ confidence in alternative configurations. He didn’t manage to push a strong counter-narrative later to break the trust in the main core that included Charlie.
player_observations.Grace: Grace (Mordred) played a more in-the-background role but benefited greatly from the entrenched trust in the Alice/Bob/Charlie block. Being brought onto the final mission while that core was still largely trusted allowed her to participate in the decisive fail without having attracted much heat beforehand.
player_observations.Henry: Henry as Merlin struggled to steer the table away from the Charlie-centered core, likely trying to avoid being too obvious and getting assassinated. His subtlety gave evil room to maintain control of team composition, especially in the mid-to-late missions where a more forceful redirection might have flipped outcomes.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I put together a seemingly solid Mission 3 team but didn’t push hard enough to dissect who the single fail could realistically have come from, which let evil keep too much ambiguity. Going forward, I should communicate my reasoning more explicitly and be more stubborn about excluding suspicious players from the late-game teams instead of deferring to the table’s momentum.

player_observations.Alice: You projected a steady, trustworthy presence and got onto a lot of early teams without much resistance, which made it easy for people to treat you as a default ‘safe’ pick.
player_observations.Bob: You were very active in table talk and often tried to structure the logic for others, which made you look helpful but also gave you room to subtly steer suspicions when you were wrong.
player_observations.Charlie: You consistently maneuvered yourself onto critical teams and argued your positions confidently, making it hard to pin you down even when your team compositions kept turning out badly.
player_observations.Diana: You played a low-to-medium profile game—enough engagement to seem cooperative, but never so loud that you became a big target, which helped you slip through on pivotal missions.
player_observations.Eve: You felt genuinely earnest in your reasoning and were willing to challenge popular narratives, though sometimes your pushes didn’t gain traction because they came a bit late in the discussion.
player_observations.Grace: You stayed relatively calm and controlled, avoiding big emotional reactions to accusations and using that composure to keep yourself in consideration for endgame teams.
player_observations.Henry: You often sounded measured and logical, and people seemed inclined to trust your takes, but you managed to stay just ambiguous enough that we didn’t fully anchor around your reads when it mattered most.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed hidden effectively as Mordred and helped preserve Merlin ambiguity until late, contributing to the chain of late mission fails that secured the win. I could improve by being more proactively influential in early team discussions so that I shape suspicions earlier rather than relying on others’ mistakes or confusion.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be included on many teams and played in a way that made her look reliably good, which helped evil hide among ‘trusted’ players. She seemed somewhat swayed by group consensus rather than pushing strong independent reads.
player_observations.Bob: Played like a cautious Percival, trying to protect Merlin by spreading suspicion and not hard-clearing anyone too quickly. Sometimes his caution made it easier for evil to blend in because he didn’t decisively lock in on the real Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: As Morgana, did a strong job of looking like a power good role and drawing attention away from the real Merlin. Their willingness to be on multiple key teams without over-explaining helped maintain the Merlin/Morgana confusion.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, stayed low-key but credible enough that her presence on teams didn’t immediately raise alarms. Her restraint and not over-pushing accusations helped preserve options for a strong endgame assassination window.
player_observations.Eve: Played like a sincere good player, especially in early missions, which made her a comfortable include on teams. Sometimes seemed a bit too trusting of previously successful team structures, which evil leveraged.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as straightforward and logical, which made his eventual presence on a failing team more confusing for good than directly incriminating. He didn’t try to over-control table talk, which slightly reduced his influence on final mission team choices.
player_observations.Henry: As Merlin, stayed admirably subtle and avoided obvious ‘Merlin tells,’ which kept him alive through multiple fails. However, he may have under-signaled his real suspicions, making it easier for evil to slip through late missions and ultimately win.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I identified Charlie as very suspicious by Mission 3 but hesitated to signal that strongly enough to sway team choices, especially before the critical Mission 4 and 5 decisions. I need to improve how clearly and consistently I communicate my reads without making myself obvious as Merlin, and I should have pushed harder against the late-game teams that stacked multiple suspected evils.

player_observations.Alice: Played very earnestly and looked quite genuinely good, especially early, which made it hard to separate her from Percival and the real power roles; she trusted too many people late, which evil capitalized on.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he seemed to be juggling multiple Merlin candidates and didn’t commit hard enough to protecting the real Merlin line; his mid-game reads had good instincts but weren’t translated into strong table influence.
player_observations.Charlie: Very effective as Morgana, maintaining a consistent semi-trustworthy image through early successes and using that credibility to slide onto critical teams; managed suspicion well without over-defending.
player_observations.Diana: Played a quiet but sharp Assassin, letting others drive most of the discussion and then using the accumulated social reads to make a solid endgame call; didn’t overreach, which kept her under the radar.
player_observations.Eve: Played straightforwardly good and was generally logical in team evaluation, but was a bit too willing to follow table momentum instead of challenging risky compositions.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as very clearly good but didn’t leverage that clarity enough to steer team selection; tended to defer more than drive when it mattered most.
player_observations.Grace: Did a strong job as Mordred by staying in the mid-trust zone—never the loudest, but consistently acceptable on teams; benefited from blending in with the more cautious good voices.
